actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Good evening, America. This is _________, and you’re watching the Science Buzz News Network. Here at SBNN, we make it our mission to provide you with what I like to call “news you can use.”

actor.name: OTHER PERSON
actor.passage: A lot of people use that phrase.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: But I invented it. How’s that for news you can use? Generally guests on Science Buzz wait to be introduced before they speak, but there are always some people with no respect for tradition. We have with us tonight, Dr. _________, a marine biologist. Now, “Doctor,” I understand you have some interesting new findings for us about sharks.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: Thank you, __________. Yes, there has been some remarkable research on sharks recently. In particular, we’re finding that sharks are repelled by certain types of metals.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Ah, you’re referring to bullets, of course.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: No, actually, it seems that some rare earth—

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Wait, so you’re trying to claim that sharks are bulletproof? I find that hard to believe.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: Well, no, not at all, but__

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: So you’re saying that sharks don’t mind getting shot? Because I think it’s a pretty safe bet that shooting a shark right in the blowhole would be a pretty good repellent.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: Sharks don’t have blowholes. You’re thinking of dolphins.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: No, you’re wrong, I’m thinking of sharks. But, fine, the fin then. Shooting a shark in the fin wouldn’t repel it?

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: …Yes, I suppose that might repel a shark.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Interesting. And what metal are these bullets made of?

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: I don’t really know. But that’s not what the study was about. We’ve found that sharks also tend to avoid certain “rare earth metals,” because of the electric field they produce when immersed in seawater.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: They electrocute the sharks?

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: Not really. Sharks have the ability to detect the small electric fields produced by animals. This helps them detect prey species of fish. The stronger electric fields produced by the chemical reaction of these metals with seawater seems to overload the sharks’ senses, and they avoid them if at all possible.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Like licking a battery. I’ll be avoiding that from now on.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: Sort of.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Or…it’s like kryptonite for sharks?

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: Yeah, actually, kind of. And if we can attach these metals to some of the huge nets used in ocean fishing, it might prevent sharks from accidentally getting caught in them.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Why would we do that? We hate sharks.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: No, we don’t. About 12 million sharks are killed every year in nets meant for other kinds of fish, and their populations are dropping rapidly.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: I hate them anyway. I don’t want to get eaten by a shark.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: But you’re in Minnesota. There aren’t any oceans in more than a thousand miles.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: There’s a river right over there. A shark could sneak right up it.

actor.name: Dr. _________
actor.passage: That’s never going to happen.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Keep your predictions to your field, my friend. That’s all we have time for tonight!
